The day is also celebrated outside the United States, with organizations in a number of countries using the day to recognize the end of slavery and to celebrate the culture and achievements of African Americans.

Thank You to everyone who attended the BSICS Inaugural Symposium on Culturally Relevant Pedagogy!

The Symposium took place on May 30, 2019 at the Gwendolyn Brooks Library on Chicago State University's campus. There was a reception with light refreshments where guests were able to meet with panelists before the symposium.

The auditorium was packed and we are still receiving positive feedback from attendees. The symposium was moderated by Dr. Kim Dulaney (Chicago State University) and the panelists were Dr. Carol D. Lee (co-Founder of Betty Shabazz International Charter Schools), Dr. Megan Bang (VP of The Spencer Foundation), and Mr. Jose Lopez (E.D, of the Puerto Rican Cultural Center).

We appreciate the support of everyone who attended and look forward to having you join us again next year!

The Race 4 The Crown is schoolwide campaign at our BASA Campus that promotes academic growth in the areas of reading and math. The school gives out small crowns at every interval of 25 assignments. At the 50th assignment mark, students are celebrated and given a crown to wear (25 Reading and Math assignments or 50 Reading or Math).

A bulletin board of smaller crowns, showcasing their hard work, will be posted in the cafeteria for all to see. The crowns will be worn on Monday mornings, beginning at this mornings drum circle.

We believe there are many ways to encourage and inspire our students towards academic excellence. And this is just one of the ways we do it. #BSICS #20YRS

Black History isn't just something to reflect on when it comes to the past. It is a rich cultural heritage of ours still being made today with a new group of innovators. We celebrate those of the past and present!

" As an advocate for education, I continue my effort to pay it forward by serving as a mentor and part-time instructor to students at Betty Shabazz International Charter School. My goal, or what I feel to rather be my responsibility as a Black man and community member here in the city of Chicago, is to continually invest in education however I can to help ensure that CPS students flourish"- Desmond Tutu Owusu, Author, Artist, BSICS Alum
